Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I got better at teaching myself complex subjects because the instructor did not know how to simplify most of them.
I feel like I didn't learn anything in the class.
Basic cell biology.  Also read of a lot of scientific papers so we developed our skills in reading and understanding those.

In this course I first had to learn how to learn. Professor Mooseker is extremely intelligent and cares a lot about his students, but does not always seem to understand that we do not understand. I had to learn how to follow his lectures before I could learn the lectures themselves. Once I could focus on the lectures I learned how to interpret experiments and data sets from the experiments. By doing this we learned about the cell membrane in a way that is not just strict memorization.
I discovered that I don't like molecular and cellular biology either.
A lot of reading and evaluating text.
Trying to understand why scientists perform the experiments they perform and what each experiment will tell about a scenario. We learnt a lot about endocytosis.

I learned about molecular and cellular biology. My critical thinking skills improved in this course because we were asked to evaluate different scenarios and predict what went wrong. I also become quite good at identifying superfluous information  which should not be underrated as a skill.

I learned so much about biology and cell membranes, much of which I'd had literally no idea about before. This course also helped me think critically and beyond memorizing and spitting out facts; I had to really understand what I was learning.

-An ability to critically read papers
-Knowledge of cellular pathways, interesting cellular features
-Some familiarity with laboratory procedures
Great knowledge in intracellular molecular workings, and mechanisms

I developed a much deeper understanding of the research methodology and experimental techniques that are used to attain the knowledge we accept as fact. I knew many of the different facts about cell biology from BIO 102 before actually taking the course, but this class helped me understand how those facts came to be accepted and helped me understand the theoretical and experimental background to these facts so that I now not only know them, but understand them.
Learned to read primary research papers.

I learned a much more in-depth analysis of biological processes within the cell. We learned to read and interpret scientific papers and how to experimentally analyze certain topics. I also learned the importance of keeping up with material because SO MUCH material is covered in this course. If you do not keep up with the material, you will be very overwhelmed come exam time.

The course helps you learn how to really think about the biological systems at hand, not just memorize the facts. It also is a good introduction to lab techniques, manipulating biological systems, understanding data, and understanding scientific papers.

I definitely learned more in this class than 101. The material is taught at a much higher level, and I developed a greater understand of the experimental set ups and processes behind much of our current understanding of cellular processes.
Really in depth knowledge about the membrane and cell biology in general - goes way beyond AP biology.
I learned a little bit more in depth on cells and different membrane exchanges important for physiology in biology.

This class taught a lot of fundamentals regarding cellular biology and the tools needed to study cell biology. I thought the topics we covered were extremely interesting, and it was helpful to read the papers for discussion section.
How to read scientific papers, how to apply experimental strategies learned in class towards new scenarios
Professor Mooseker moves quickly through a high volume of very in-depth material; however, it is presented in a way that can be understood.
Improved problem solving skills and ability to synthesize information in order to solve a problem. Learned how to design my own experiments.

Although this course was honestly unlike any biology course I've ever taken before (i.e. much more difficult and fast-paced than 101), it was a really good class to start thinking more critically about how things/pathways/organelles/you name it interact and work together - which is a good thing. It was also a good introduction to begin absorbing and learning a lot of information since there are only 2 exams, so you need to be able to know what's going on

Helpful if you have had some biology laboratory experience!
Learned about cells on a micro level, like endocytotic and exocytotic pathways, plasma membrane proteins, etc.
Critically reading scientific articles, thinking experimentally instead of theoretically.

Learned so much. Looking back, I didn't realize how much I learned until the class was over. Invaluable material that can only be taught this way, no matter how hard people say the class's teaching style is.

I gained knowledge of the functions of a cell and how cellular organisms develop, function, and survive. New skills were gained concerning how these cellular organisms can be viewed and studied to gain further insights of their functions.

Biol 102 taught me a lot about cell membranes and cell biology that I had not been previously exposed to. The material is just completely different from high school bio, and I think the level of depth students are expected to develop with the content is also new. I definitely learned a lot not only knowledge-wise but also learning skills-wise through this course.
I love biology and this was a great intro class

I learned about the techniques scientists use to experiment on cells at a molecular level. In this class, not only did we gain the tools to perform our own experiments, but we learned about some of the greatest experiments throughout history, and what they proved. Along the way, I also learned a great deal more about the individual components of cells: Endoplasmic Reticulum, Golgi, Lysosome, Cell Membrane, Membrane Proteins, Actin Filaments and Microtubules. There was a large amount of material covered in this class, but it was manageable and very interesting.

The most useful skill I developed from this course was being able to read and understand journal articles exponentially better than I could before. I also learned a lot about cell systems and, more importantly, how to apply this knowledge to questions an actual scientist might encounter.

I learned a lot about the lipid bilayer, endocytosis, exocytosis, experimental techniques, and more. The class covers A LOT of material. You need to make sure you stay on top of it, and most importantly pay close attention in class.

This foundation course in Cell Biology was an extremely impactful course for me in enhancing my analytical skills and critical thinking when applied to biological situations. Instead of focusing on what are considered the biological facts of cells and membranes, this course looked at the experimental techniques that were used in order to make and theorize these systems. I found that the lessons were very engaging and personal as we were asked to think and recreate experimental methods rather than simply memorize the ideas, and it made my learning process much more meaningful.
I learned a lot about the physiology of the cell.
I enhanced my skills in cell biology.
I learned the basics of cell bio. What components make up the subject and what makes them work in unison. I also learned what happens when many of these systems malfunction or are mutated.

In this class I did learn a lot about how biologists discovered different concepts and principles in cell biology. However the biggest takeaway from this class was teaching myself a bunch of cell bio because lecture was extremely unhelpful.
A wide variety of concepts. In great detail. Especially related to membrane mechanics

BIOL 102 really gave me the ability to look at novel concepts and idea from the eyes of a scientist. There's virtually no other way to explain it. I came into the class thinking it was the hardest shit ever and I left thinking it was easy. It took a lot of hard work, don't get me wrong, but the skillset I acquired far outshines the effort I had to put into the class--100% worth it, especially for anyone wanting to go into the natural sciences in any degree.

I learned how to think critically with science. I really liked how the course focused not just on facts, but on thinking more generally and having to think about broad concepts, like a scientist. I also learned a huge amount about cell biology. But like I said, I think the most important skills I gained were problem solving and thinking about concepts and thinking critically, not just repeating and memorizing facts.

A lot about cell and membrane biology. Specifically, I learned a lot about experimental biology, and the techniques used to learn about biology. I also became much more confident and capable of reading scientific papers.
This course taught me the ability to think scientifically on complex topics and apply knowledge to experiments rather than just spit back information.

Learned a lot about the methodology and experimental approach of biological research. The class still requires quite a fair amount of memorization as does any bio class, but it strives to focus more on problem-solving in a lab setting.
Cellular biology
I gained so much new knowledge on the topics in the curriculum. I also developed new study habits as a result of the course.
Problem solving skills.
studying habits and lecture engagement
I developed my critical thinking skills and how to apply my knowledge to new situations.
Learned about cells

I have improved much in my ability to think like a scientist in this course. Professor Mooseker challenged us to understand not only the facts behind biological systems, but also the origin of our understanding of it through experimental evidence and scientific publishings.

I felt that the class was moved at a pace where it was difficult to understand class material. As the class progressed, I was forced to learn the material on my own time. This was a new skill, as I had never had to review recently-learned class material outside of class. This helped me be more proactive in learning concepts that I didn't understand during lecture. When I learned how to better succeed in the course, which was during the second half of this module, I recognized that I had to put more effort and begin studying for the final much farther in advance than I had ever before for courses in high school. This made me learn the material at such a deeper level, and I felt much more secure in my knowledge of the material. Following the final, I feel very confident in my understanding of the second half of the module's curriculum.
I believe that this course has prepared me to advance in my cell biology studies. I thoroughly enjoyed the concepts that we explored and hope to study more cell biology in the future.
A great foundation in cellular biology, understanding of experimental methods
I gained valuable insight into how to apply biology to real-world situations that are not just fact-based but require an integration of learned information, skills, and techniques.
I learned how to apply information about biology to new problems and work with a large amount of challenging material.

I was able to vastly expand my knowledge of biological experiments and molecular processes. In terms of skills, I am now able to design experiments, find faults in experiments, or identify the purpose of one.
I learned about cell biology and experiments that are important for the discovery of cell biology.
Not a ton. Mostly just confusion about what I was supposed to be learning.
I learned how to fudge my way through experiment designs for lab procedures I didnt understand.

Critically analysing scientific papers 
Applying understood concepts to new data sets
I feel I increased in my ability to memorize material and have a better basis for an understanding of biology.
Experimental design. Factual knowledge
Basic laboratory skills for biological research
If I knew, I'd tell you.
This course gave me a new insight into cell biology. This is definitely one of the first courses where most everything was completely new to me.
Basic biology knowledge
A great deal of experimental insights were taught, which was probably the hardest and most tedious parts of the course. Along with this much textbook-type information was presented as well.
I learned a great deal about membrane physiology and research techniques that will aid me in the future.
the course was very much based on experimental evidence and experimental analysis of the concepts we learned in class.

The intentions of the class include developing the student's ability to read and comprehend scientific papers as well as understand certain areas of cell biology. In terms of knowledge, I certainly gained some about cell bio. In terms of skills, I do not feel as if I really gained anything. It was easy to attend section without fully reading the papers and still participate completely.

I learned about cell membranes. I learned about techniques used to carry out scientific investigations in biology.  I learned about the experiments completed to gain the understanding of cell and membrane biology we have today.
reading scientific papers!

I gained an introductory but in-depth understanding of cell biology, including in particular cellular membranes. In addition, I learned a lot about current experimental techniques in biology (the toolkits) and improved my reading of primary scientific literature.
I gained a fairly comprehensive knowledge of cell biology and experimental techniques.

I learned how to analyze the information we learned in class and apply it to real world situations.  I learned a lot more about biology and how to apply the principles we learned in 101 to the information we learned in 102. I gained a much better understanding of the inner workings of the cell.
This was an overview course of cell biology that also focused heavily on laboratory procedures.

This class was designed to provide a basic introduction to the properties of the cell membrane and scientific processes used to discover them.  The class was focused equally on learning WHAT a thing was, HOW it worked, and WHY we can prove that.  These three aims were not always taught equally, however.
I learned a lot about laboratory techniques commonly used in biology. I also learned a lot about experimental problem solving and being able to properly dissect scientific research papers.
I gained a broad foundation of the rudiments of cell biology. I also learned and developed experimental skills and strategies as well as how to interpret novel data sets.
I learned how to read scientific journal articles more critically

I really liked this course because of it taught students to apply knowledge rather than memorize it. I learned a lot about membrane composition, structure, and function, as well as numerous cell mechanisms from protein synthesis to muscle contraction. I learned so much from working in the PSets in groups and in the review sessions. The fact that the class was so challenging is also what made it a valuable learning experience, because it required constant effort and discussion to stay on top of the material.

I learned that peer tutors and enrichment sessions are essential because of the fast paced nature of the lecture. Personally I need the extra explanations. Doing homework with other students was also incredibly helpful.
Critical thinking when applied to biological issues and situations.
none
Learned how to read a biology paper. Learned a lot about biological experiments and various movement processes in cells.
This course makes students think in a different way. Facts are no longer the key to success.

Overview of several fields in cell biology, including protein secretory pathway, cell mobility and cytoskeleton, and membrane properties. Focus on landmark papers and studies that led to current knowledge on these mechanisms.

I developed a better ability to think scientifically; how can I apply experimental methods to study things that are often difficult to observe directly? Through learning the concepts and working through homework assignments I developed the mindset of a scientist.
This course not only taught me scientific facts, but it also taught me how to determine those facts from experiments.
A lot of experiments
I learned to read scientific papers critically. I was also able to apply the material from lectures in understanding these papers

The value of this class is in developing scientific reasoning. I learned a lot about reasoning through problems and thinking like a scientist. There is also significant focus on reading published science papers.

I learned a great deal about cellular biology, especially concentrated in a few areas (membranes, protein synthesis and targeting, endocytosis and motor functions). The greatest takeaway from this course however was how to set up experiments to test theories and how to analyze data sets to learn more about the cell.

Biology at Yale is just memorising a lot of information. Although the course was about applying the information, the bulk of learning was just comprised of memorizing the names and functions of specific genes or proteins.
This class isn't about memorizing mountains of information (though you still do this). This class is meant to develop critical thinking skills and has helped me think like a scientist.
Biology of the cell and membranes
I learned about cell biology, with a focus on cell membranes and protein synthesis. I gained insight into experimental evidence for what we know about cells.

This was an incredible course. Although I struggled through it, I throughly enjoyed the material and the challenge that a course like this brought with it. In this course I learned to study biology at a deeper level than ever before (before this all I did was memorization) and actually learned to understand concepts and mechanisms of molecular biology. Moreover, I learned to read research papers and discuss them in a journal club format.

I gained a lot of knowledge about processes of the production and distribution of proteins throughout the cell, I gained the ability to better understand experimental data, and I gained an insight into the extreme complexity of the cell.

The material taught in this course is extremely difficult, but also interesting. Having a class this difficult, where just to understand the material requires a lot more effort than doing the reading and attending lecture teaches you a lot. We were forced to truly understand the material and apply it.
I gained a greater insight into how research works. I gained an understanding of how cells work and how researchers can use methods to study cell functions and organelles.

The best part of the course was Julie Park; I think I spent an average of 6 hours a week at enrichment, peer tutoring, and taking advantage of all the resources she put in place. I believe the professor really cares about learning, and I really appreciated the props he would bring in to illustrate key concepts, but I felt that he rushed through the material and often it was very difficult to understand what he was saying.
The course is good at pushing its students. The main weakness is that the teacher is not good at explaining most of the information, which is essential given that most of the info is completely new.

The structure of the class was not conducive to my learning styles. The professor only used scientific jargon and never simplified anything. He would ask these questions that we were expected to know, but never gave us the learning tool to answer them.

One weakness is the whistles that were passed out at the beginning of the course. I admire the purpose of them and they seemed to be helpful but for much of the course I was just so lost that I was afraid to blow the whistle because I could not even formulate a question of what I did not know. The class size really can't be helped because of the huge demand for the class, but having a smaller class would have really benefited me. I would have been more free to ask questions. A strength of the class is that the peer tutors and Teaching Fellows sit among the class in lecture. It really helped me to converse with the peer tutor, Alon Millet, during lecture and ask questions so I didn't get completely lost because of one small detail.

Strengths include the teaching staff's knowledge of and experience with the material, and flexibility concerning being asked questions and slowing down to comprehensively teach material.

Weaknesses include the organization of the course material. Sometimes, it feels like a lot of information at once.

For those who really enjoy biology, the way the course is set up caters to those with a great deal of interest and knowledge of the subject. For others, however, it can be difficult to feel like it's worthwhile to actually engage yourself. Even though there are enrichment sessions, that doesn't prevent the actual lecture from being troublesome.

It is interesting with interesting material. I like the mid-term and the final. I think the peer tutors this semester were AWESOME! I think the class is too long and no matter how many demos are done or interactive questions are included, it is just hard for students to stay attentive all though the lecture and the way the class is, if you miss one part of the lecture, then you are kind of lost for the rest of it. The whistles are also a good addition I think. It would be cool to have lab visits and see in practicality what we are talking about in theory.

The strength of the course lies entirely in the way it makes students think and forces them to absorb information and apply it instead of regurgitate it. The organization of the course was vexing. Although the professor encouraged us to ask him to slow down, we often didn't, and he zipped along covering 70-80 powerpoint slides in 75 minutes every class. The sheer volume of information was paralyzing at times, however his problem sets and exams were very fair and frankly, enjoyable, once you got the hang of it. While this is a minor suggestion, I would request that in future semesters when the powerpoints are posted online they are labelled not just by lecture but by content e.g. Unit 4-5.5

I honestly think the class time is too long, it's hard to be engaged throughout and actively learn over the course of 75min. I also wish we'd gotten more feedback on our tests, I didn't always fully understand why I had points taken off.

This course was like drinking from a fire hose, but in a good way. The material is interesting and lectures/sections were engaging. More defined test prep would be helpful. We had no practice questions aside from the P-sets. These were helpful, but did not expose us to many types of things we were expected to decipher. Clearer explanations of mistakes on psets and the midterm would have helped.

The content on cellular functions was wonderful and the demonstrations were great. Real-world applications and pictures being a part of the class were good because often biology classes miss out on that real-world aspect. I loved learning about the experiments behind these concepts, it definitely helped my critical thinking skills.

At the beginning of the year we learned a lot about experimental methods and had to know specifics regarding the methods - i.e. reagents. I wish this had been more conceptual, for example not having to know the reagents for density-gradient sedimentation -- it's hard to remember if we haven't applied them in the lab. Generally, learning about these tools was very helpful for the class though.

The whistles were great, but I always felt too awkward to blow my whistle in front of everyone.
Weaknesses: Professor goes a bit fast

One of the greatest weaknesses is that lecture goes so fast. At the same time, I understand that there's a lot of material to cover, but if your biology background isn't fairly strong, it can be difficult to keep up. One of the best things about this course was enrichment, just going over the material in more streamlined fashion every week was very helpful.

The content of BIO 102 is very comprehensive and is fascinating. Professor Mooseker does a great job of explaining the different experimental methodologies used and their importance. The sections are also well organized and improved through the semester, each covering a different research paper relevant to the course content. This constant interplay of theory and experimentation has been really helpful in allowing me to fully understand this content. 

The course does go very quickly, and because of the way in which questions are structured, it is sometimes hard for students to fully grasp a concept before the lecturer has already moved on and is discussing something different. The whistles work for the students who are confident enough to ask questions as they think of them, but many students need more time to process the content before they think of questions or they realize they don't understand something.

In that vein, I think this class would really benefit from a flipped classroom style of learning. Having prerecorded lectures would make this course more organized by forcing the teaching staff to know exactly what they will cover before the lectures, and it would allow the students to be more productive in their questions during class. The Sunday review sessions were often much clearer and more helpful than the actual lectures for me because of how focused the questions were, given that the material had already been covered at least once.
It would be better if there were more clear piazza answers/questions - a lot of the time answers were not monitored or made the material more confusing.
Professor Mooseker is very knowledgeable, but is not the best at communicating this knowledge to students in a easy-to-understand and interesting way. Lectures were very boring and hard to follow.
I would make it possible to somehow have more hands on experience since the content is very very experiment orientated

The Sunday afternoon review sessions were very helpful to stay on track with the course. I also felt that toolkit sections at the beginning of the course were useful later on in understanding experiments. The class does mover very fast, but the questions asked help slow the pace and make it easier to keep up in lecture.

I learned so much information from the class, but I do feel like the material went too in depth for an introductory class. At times, it was extremely hard to follow because the material was so dense, to the point where 90% of the material extended far beyond AP biology. The peer tutors were really great though, so it's really helpful to attend all of their sessions.

I thought the class was taught poorly by the professor since I couldn't seem to learn any material from attending lectures or any of his review sessions. I disliked how the focus of the discussion sections was on papers rather than the content of the class, but I understand the importance of that exposure and the relation to the material. I liked the enrichment sections and was able to learn much better from her than from the professor. I also liked the idea of the red questions and the whistles that allowed us to ask questions.

The strength of this course is the fact that Professor Mooseker really wants to help us learn the foundations of biology. Unfortunately, there are many weaknesses to this course, as with the entire intro bio sequence here at Yale. First of all, the content that was tested upon relied heavily upon research knowledge; this is fine in the sense that we are supposed to develop those skills in this course. However, people who had done research before coming to Yale had a huge advantage over everyone else, making it very hard to do well if you didn't have research experience before Yale. The other issue in this course is that there is very little support and clarity from the teaching staff. Everything is always very shrouded in mystery, no one wants to give an answer to simple questions about test material or content, and some of the TSs are not great. It was a frustrating course to go through because it seems like the course is entirely designed to trick students and make them dislike biology.
The course definitely covers a large volume of high-level material, but it can seem at times that some of the more basic material is either skipped or taken for granted.

Strengths= Professor is extremely knowledgeable 
Weaknesses= too much information and not enough time to process it. Large lecture hall makes it difficult to truly understand information

Sometimes Prof. Mooseker will go fast over the slides and not explain things too in depth, which can lead to a lot of people being lost in lecture, but for the most part, if you focus for the lecture, follow the slides as they progress, and "whistle" (they hand out whistles at the beginning of 102 so you can signal when you have a question, and Prof. Mooseker is very receptive to questions), then you'll be good and on top of things for the time being. Prof. Mooseker is very receptive on questions in lecture; sometimes it's difficult to hear him though; Prof. Park is amazing when it comes to discussion section and enrichment; Prof. Mooseker holds review sessions once every week to go over material and that is very helpful for refreshing the material - definitely recommend going to those if possible; also really liked having constant exposure to primary source papers - very helpful in knowing how to analyze and interpret figures and text

The course is really difficult because the teacher goes super fast in class, it's hard to follow what he's talking about, and then the tests are really hard applications of what we learned. Discussion sections were good though. This could be improved by going slowly and organizing the information better in class.

Throughout delivery of the material, there was consistent emphasis on experimental strategies, so most concepts learned were grounded in practical applications. I think this is a good place in the intro bio sequence to introduce us to more rigorous, and less theoretical, biology.

However, lectures could sometimes be too fast-paced, an abrupt change from lectures in BIOL 101 which were delivered more slowly and carefully. While it is possible to catch on a few lectures in, perhaps the first few lectures could be slower, to allow students to process information before moving on.

While Piazza was a useful learning tool, particularly to see what questions my coursemates had about the material, the sheer number of questions in the buildup to exams was not ideal for gaining information. There could be come mechanism for separating what are agreed upon as good questions, from those that demand explanations about material on the slides.

Strengths: well-formatted, professor was brilliant, TAs are helpful

weaknesses: some TAs told students more info than others, it became unfair, too many slides happened in 1 lecture, sometimes terms were said without being explained (definitions could flash on the slides), too big of room

Strengths: This class, while very difficult, gives students the time and space to learn the material. Whether it be in class, in section, or in peer tutoring, it is possible to understand the material in depth. 

Weaknesses: Not enough people take advantage of the peer tutoring sessions. Those things got me through the course, and I think everyone could benefit from those hours.

Much covered during the course but at times it felt as if it was too much that was covered. Although it was fine to ask questions during lecture, it feels as if not enough were asked of individuals, myself included, did not wish to seem inferior compared to peers who were fully knowledgeable on the topic at hand.

The course is great in that the material is all pretty new and very interesting. Also, the instructor and peer tutors and course director and TAs are all very accessible and very invested in student learning. I also find that the homework practice sets are really helpful and engaging for student understanding. The only "weakness" of this class is that the material is super fast-paced. We cover hundreds of slides every lecture (and basically all of the slides have important details on them). However, in retrospect, I feel that I've gained a lot of knowledge from this course as well.

I felt that this course was very well put together compared to my other courses. There were helpful TAs and peer tutors, and Professor Mooseker made it clear that he was always willing to be flexible with the class. He used whistles to allow students to stop the lecture and ask questions; this was the most helpful tool by far, and it made the lecture load more manageable. The homeworks were difficult but not unmanageable, and they didn't take hours. Also, the peer tutors were FANTASTIC!!! They provided extra practice and homework help when needed. Biology 102 was a very well-run class!

A strength of the course was how it taught me to "think like a scientist." 
Weaknesses: it was very difficult to pay attention during the lectures. An hour and 15 minutes is a long time, and I think I would have been much more engaged if there were 3 50 minute lectures a week instead of two 75 minute ones. Also, it would have been nice to have weekly quizzes as in Bio 101, as that would have motivated me to stay on top of the material a lot better and thus be able to connect with what was happening in class instead of it all going over my head.

The class is very fast-paced. It would have been helpful to slow down at certain points, especially since it's hard to process a lot of these concepts, the vast majority of which I had no background in.

It is a very engaging course with a lot of material, but I did not find it overwhelming. Everything that was taught felt meaningful and the way we incorporated biological ideas into our toolkit of applied knowledge made my learning much more deep and impactful than I expected. If there was anything that could change, I think the discussion sessions where we analyzed peer review papers in groups should have group discussion of the entire paper prioritized rather than small groups focusing on one figure and sharing their presentation with the class, as I would understand the part I presented very well but have a more cursory knowledge of the other portions of the paper.

I think this course has the potential to be amazing. The problem is that this course is SOOOO much material that if one thing is missed then it is hard to keep up. I believe that this course should be filmed so students can go back and watch the lecture. I also think that this course is way too much to be only a half a credit.

I think that this class was great for people who learn really well from slides, but lacked other means of teaching. I also think that sometimes Professor Mooseker assumed we had a better knowledge of the material than we did in actuality. 
I wish that there were better review sessions especially for the first test because I didn't know what to expect.

This course is very specific. I did not really like the lecturing style. Also, the material is highly tailored, so you have to be interested in certain aspects of cell biology to actually like the course.

The class covers a lot of material and teaches us to problem solve in the field of biology by ourselves which was great. However, he covered too much material too fast and it was really hard to keep up with the material. Without enrichment, I could not have passed this class.

The possible one strength of this class is teaching students how to read primary literature. The weaknesses, however, far outnumber the strengths. The lecture material is thrown at you at such a fast rate that it's hard to digest in any way unless you've already learned how scientists discovered basic principles of cell biology. In addition, there was much less structure than in BIOL101, where certain topics were scheduled to be taught on certain days. BIOL102, by comparison, feels all over the place. The lecture slides are much less helpful and lecturer even more so.

The course is very informative but a great challenge. In my opinion, it is quite inaccessible to students without an extensive biology background. Without enrichment, I would have possibly failed the assessments.

I think the course made it very easy to learn the material, as long as you did work outside of class as well. The concepts covered were very well explained, and I think this course was great about making sure the concepts were understood by everyone. The concept of whistles was a great addition because it helped make sure nobody got left behind. I also think throwing in the red questions was very helpful in making us think critically throughout the course and be engaged during lectures, rather than just sitting and listening for over an hour. I didn't think there were any big weaknesses. One thing is that on homeworks I sometimes was not always able to access the feedback, so sometimes I didn't totally understand what concepts I didn't get.

This course covers a lot of material that is very interesting. The lectures are very boring and difficult to follow. I don't think I ever learned a  lot of information that I later retained from a lecture. I had to rely on my own individual studying a lot.

Though I enjoyed a majority of the  content of this course, I found it difficult to engage during lecture because I often had a difficult time hearing the professor due to mumbling. I also found it difficult to follow lectures and was very grateful for the peer tutors and for enrichment to catch me up.

I thought the professor/teaching staff were incredible in that they were always looking for ways to help explain things, they were willing to meet with you to help with any questions, and they were all around very encouraging. I also loved the peer tutors and the organization of the class. However, I felt that the class often moved very quickly, and think it would be better if the class moved a bit slower and maybe have the material a bit more condensed.
I love the idea of the class, but in reality, it was extremely difficult to follow most of the time. The material itself is quite interesting but perhaps there is just too much of it.

Sometimes the lectures are difficult to follow even with Professor Mooseker's help. It would be great if we could receive an overview of the entire system before we dive into the specifics. The course does a great job of teaching its students more about biology than pure memorization.
great course, they simply go way too quickly.
Strengths are an interesting and very knowledgeable teacher and teaching fellows. Weaknesses may be the structure of the course; it may not work well for those with varying study habits.
The professor doesn't really focus on the basic information and assumes you know all the things. His lectures are a little unorganized.
incredibly challenging content that helped me grow.
The lectures are very dry and from the slides. The large size of the lecture makes it hard to change this and it would be much more beneficial to do discussion section type classes.

The powerpoint could be vastly improved. It has a lot of good, important information, but it is not a useful tool for professor mookeker during lecture. There is too much information and small writing on each slide, so they are pretty impossible to read through during lecture. I also didn't like the "pre" and "Post" lecture slides system. Streamline the canvas folders and the presentations, and the course will be much better! Other than that it was pretty good.
The professor urged us to "blow our whistles" to ask questions and get clarification. For me, this was great in theory but difficult in practice because I rarely had specific enough questions to ask.

The course could be improved in terms of how it was taught. I (and all of the students in the class who I had discussed this with) felt that the pace of lecture was too fast, and too much material was covered in every lecture. In almost every lecture, I (and others) felt completely lost--so lost to the point that I couldn't even ask a specific question because I had so little understanding of the broader concepts. While Prof. Mooseker is a brilliant researcher and kind man, he isn't the best-paced lecturer. Some improvements could be changing the discussion sections to be more review-based since the course is so dense instead of doing the "journal club." While I genuinely enjoyed reading the papers, I felt that it would've been more productive and helpful to our understanding if we reviewed course material during section instead of papers that vaguely related to the concepts from lecture.
However, some strengths include the peer tutoring sessions and Prof. Park's general graciousness and help!

This course covers a lot of information in a short period of time. Thus, it would have been helpful if the lectures were more organized so that I could better grasp the material. Lectures tended to jump all over the place, making them hard to follow and somewhat confusing. One real strength of this course was enrichment. Enrichment was where I truly felt I began to understand the material covered in class. I think this is due to the fact that it was held in a smaller setting and was much more organized.

I enjoyed the structure of the course, with learning about scientific papers in discussion section. I also enjoyed the interactive format of the lectures. If anything could be changed, I would cover more cell biology topics rather than the ones that we covered in detail.
Lectures arent super well organized
Interesting content and lecture organization, PowerPoint slides could be better organized
The lectures were incredibly boring and that lowered my incentive to attend class.

The strength of this course is that it pushes the student to engage in outside-of-the-box thinking and exposes the students to scientific papers and journal club discussions. I cannot think of any major weaknesses.

The strength was that the material is very interesting. The weakness is that it was presented in a confusing and unclear manner for students. It is also a huge jump in difficulty of material and examination for students after 101
This course is interesting and challenging but was somewhat difficult to understand through lecture.

This courses main weakness was the pace of the lectures. The amount of material covered made it hard to prepare for each class and hard to absorb the content. A main disadvantage of this is that it prevents you from asking the professor questions during class since most of your learning of the material occurs outside of lecture. Strengths include the applicability of the course content and exposure to lots of material.
This course goes too into depth without covering the basics first. Very easy to get lost.
There was a lot of info. He said we didn't have to know facts but we most certainly did... we just didn't know which facts or which kind of fact.
This course was not taught well. The professor did not explain things or teachhe just presented massive amounts of information and expected us to teach ourselves.

This course is set up in a way that does not benefit people who have never taken an advanced high school biology course. The lectures assume previous knowledge and are difficult to follow without previous understanding.

I think Professor Mooseker is very kind and obviously a genius but I literally was unable to learn anything from him. His voice is really difficult to not fall asleep to and he provided literally no background information before launching into complex topics. The peer tutors were the only thing that let me pass this class.
Lectures should be video recorded because it is hard to catch every detail with how fast the material is taught

Mooseker is obviously someone who was around for biology in its heyday and is just excited to blab about the things he helped discover. However, that doesn't make for a course structure that's very conducive to learning. He'll go through 200 slides a lecture if you let him, and if I ever had been able to follow him enough to ask questions and slow him down, I would've.
The toolkit units, though helpful, are really difficult to understand given the absence of some sort of lab course or demonstration.

Because this is a difficult course that covers a lot of material, I think it would be helpful if discussion sessions were used solely to review and discuss material learned in lecture, not for reading papers. While I understand the value of reading the papers and that the papers are related to course material, I still think it would be helpful for section to be more about review (more BIOL 101 style) than new material.

Strength: muscle biochemistry and actin polymerization are super cool.
Weakness: Mooseker goes through 100 PowerPoint  slides in 75 minutes. Not cool.

Both Professors made it much more difficult to understand the concepts in my opinion. I found that Professor Park explained things in a much more comprehensive way. I think that the Mooseker sometimes forgot to explain things on a baseline level.

A weakness is that the space for peer tutoring is always too small, and that students with previous AP biology experience are basically automatically unable to participate in enrichment regardless of what the AP biology experience in high school was actually like. I found that, especially because the course is challenging, the support given more individually to students was lacking at times.

Weaknesses of the course: lectures are fairly boring, led me not to pay attention. Section leaders were unreliable in terms of knowledge and understanding. It was too easy to attend section without actually having read the papers.
The lecture was so big it was hard to understand anything. Julie park is the true teacher for this course. Itd be better if she could teach lecture.
This course moved at a very fast pace, and the lectures were confusing and not very engaging.

The strengths: The homework sets are helpful for learning. The course instructors provide lots of resources for students, and are open to student input and questions. The weaknesses: despite many efforts to organize the course, it is extremely disorganized. It is difficult to leave lecture with a concrete sense of what has been learned during class that day, because the curriculum jumps around so much.  The professor states learning goals, but fails to achieve these learning goals and certainly does not give a recap of the learning goals at the end of the class. I think this could help (answers to the learning goals included in the recap!). A weakness of this course is that students receive no feedback about their learning prior to the midterm, which is an enormous portion of the overall grade. Professor Mooseker, as he told us the first day, "hates quizzes," but I believe there should be some other way for students to assess their knowledge, reinforce their knowledge, and potentially accumulate points along the way. The homework sets are not enough. Section leaders for this course are also a weakness.  My personal TA was very difficult to understand and did not seem to comprehend the course material well.  When Professor Park visited a section of ours (the final one), my TA had to be corrected multiple times by Professor Park, and Professor Park had to supplant her teaching with additional follow-up questions which apparently we should have been prompted to answer by our TA.  I felt more confident in the information shared by my peers than by my TA instructor during section each week.
This course had an unengaging lecture. Mooseker went through the slides very quickly and did not explain the concepts well.

I think this class overall has a ton of strengths: the application, not memorization, based tests, the reading of the scientific papers, and the red questions in lecture to practice for exams. The class did not have a lot of weaknesses by any means, but one is that we did received grades but not receive feedback on homework assignments, and even by comparing to the answer key it was difficult to understand why we'd lost points.

I like how the test questions are mostly based on experiments, because it requires students to have a very thorough knowledge of both the actual material and the experimental techniques. 

I did miss the way BIOL 101 discussions worked, where we went over the material people were confused on. I think that would have been more helpful rather than having a paper to read for all 5 discussion sections.

I think the course would be better if we were to have weekly quizzes like in 101. It forces students to review the material as we go along instead of all at once at the end.  I thought that Professor Julie Park did a fantastic job in running the enrichment sessions and running the course overall. The enrichment sessions helped me a lot and made me feel comfortable asking questions.

Our professor was engaging and was very ready to answer questions but the major weakness was the extremely large amount of information covered. It was pretty overwhelming and the concepts are not easy to understand already. If that amount of information had been spread over a semester, it would have still been a challenging course.

The greatest strengths of this course are the papers.  I have not taken biology for a long time, and it was very difficult for me to become reacquainted with the biological sciences and terminology.  I have, however, been reading scientific journal articles in other disciplines.  I was able to learn from the journal articles much more effectively than from the lecture or powerpoint.
On a similar note, the experiments presented in lecture made it very easy for me to understand the processes.  I think more time spend on explaining WHY we know what we know would improve the course.

The strength was I feel like I learned a lot of valuable material. Learning about experimental techniques is more important than simply memorizing facts. The weakness is it was horrifically taught and therefore I taught myself everything.
The way the course was taught via powerpoint was a strength and weakness of the class. The class was too quickly paced, but the information was presented well and thoroughly.
The course material is interesting but the lecture is very large and fast.
I love the class as it is. My only dream would have been to have such a class as a seminar rather than a huge lecture.

A strength was that enrichment sessions were offered however there was not enough room for everyone that wanted to take it. Alon is also an incredible peer tutor and I am very grateful that this course had him. 

However not all section leaders were as good as others. I felt that I was behind simply because my section leader would not explain things well or fully. She would go over time. It was incredibly difficult to understand her also.
More practice material for the first midterm would have been very helpful, since I didn't know what I was getting into.

Strengths: allowing students to participate during lecture when we have questions; homework helps with understanding the material

Weaknesses: way too much material, at a higher level than introductory biology. If you didn't take a high-level biology class in high school, it is impossible to follow. Even if you did, lecture can be impossible to follow because there is so much material covered so quickly, and the topics do not flow logically from one to the other, which also makes it hard to keep up.
Bombards your brain with a load of material in hopes that you will retain about 60% of it.
It is a large lecture which means there are opportunities for misunderstandings and confusion but it is compensated with sections and peer tutoring.

Strengths: Engaging, interesting, excellent teacher
Weaknesses: Too much material covered in a short period of time
Experimental and historical focus is good for motivation. Content could have been more clearly presented but overall very well delivered.

The strengths are that many experimental techniques, along with scientific critical thinking skills are taught, however, the weaknesses are that many fundamental topics are not covered sufficiently. There should be another introductory biology class for students who have not already taken AP Biology, or similar courses, or this course should slow down its pace.

The course is good at developing a scientific mindset in students, not just memorizing facts but applying knowledge in order to develop new insights and new discoveries. The course material is generally engaging and challenging, for an introductory course. I would prefer if Prof. Mooseker devoted more time at the beginning of each unit connecting the content we were going to explore to some of the more basic ideas and knowledge that we may have been familiar with in high school. That way, I would have an easier method of anchoring all the new knowledge to my previous knowledge.
I think the whistles helped a lot to slow down the lectures, although at times it was still hard to take notes as fast as Professor Mooseker was going through slides.

I found this course incredibly boring. Usually I can find something about any class to make it interesting for me, but here I was at a loss. While Bio 101 took jargon-filled information and made it interesting by building upon itself to the point where we could understand pertinent research papers on important issues such as HIV, I felt that this course was disconnected and left me with little usable knowledge about the cell. My TF was great, I must say, but I felt very little motivation to go to the actual lecture.

One strength is that this course split up the material into "Units" and "Toolkits" so that we could learn the necessary experimental methods for learning the content.

One weakness was that this course crammed a lot of information into so short of a time on top of having a long lecture. This made it hard to retain all of the information during the lecture simply because there was so much information coming at me. This could possibly be improved by having the course spread out over 3 days a week instead of having a long lecture twice a week.

Obviously, the professors and TA are passionate about biology and about teaching biology. I did learn a lot of interesting material, and I enjoyed reading the journal articles. However, this class was very hard for me, as I didn't take AP biology and have never worked in a biology lab. The expectations for understanding concepts in this class were so high, and we moved so quickly.

My main problem with this course is that the lectures are very erratic and nothing can be gained from the lecture notes. The lectures jump around from topics that do not seem at all connected which makes them really hard to follow. I found the weekly sections very useful and my TA was great!
This class was ridiculously hard and had very little to do with biology and more about the experiments that founded biology.

Weakness: sheer size, but it is an intro class
Strength: engaged peer tutors

The strengths were largely centered on skills outside the actual learning of biology. As I mentioned above, the class did a very good job at teaching scientific reasoning.

However, the class did a fairly poor job at teaching many important parts of biology. While I certainly learned a great deal about 4 or 5 ultra specific concepts, I find it troubling that as first year biology students, we will never have learned about cellular respiration, photosynthesis, or the mitochondria. I hope in the future there is greater emphasis on more general concepts and perhaps less of an emphasis on several specific things.

Strengths: the primary sources of information (EM images, data sets), the teaching expertise, the discussions sections and peer tutoring were great supplementals to the course,  the problem sets were challenging but well desgined

Weaknesses: the lectures were very difficult to follow making it hard to understand the material without individual studying (I usually left lost and confused)
Less memorization, more application. Knowing a bunch of protein names and functions is not productive in an age when things like that can just be looked up.

This course is very engaging and challenging. It also is structured in a very coheisive way. The biggest downside would be the amount of information i had to memorize, but that is soemthing that can't be avoided when studying biology.
Cover less topics but more in depth

It was good that the experiments, once understood, where a bit redundant/used a lot of the same principles they were core throughout. However, the other materials we had to know was overwhelming, and rarely did I ever understand what was happening during lecture. I had to go back by myself and take apart things one by one. The pace, I think, was too quick. For the second exam, we had over 500 slides to memorize and commit to memory. It was a lot. I know I had to study for at least 14-20 hours for each exam.
Mark is a great person and really does care about use understanding the subjects, it was just hard for some people to see that with all that was thrown at us.


Piazza was really helpful!
Very unorganized, very long lecture notes that costed too much to print

The lectures are not well-designed to teach. They do not cover the basics/foundational material before throwing students in the deep end. They are disorganized. They go too quickly. I think the idea of focusing on experimental design and evidence is a cool one, but that doesn't mean you should have dense slides listing indecipherable experimental procedures without explanation and without teaching us what we need to know to understand them first. The test and homework questions could also use some work. You have the right idea--presenting students with an experiment/new data that they have to apply concepts to-- but sometimes what the questions are really testing is if students have remembered some small detail.

Very difficult course, professor goes a little bit too fast, but is very kind and at times very funny and engaging.  Overall, I'm sure it is good preparation for the future, it was just a stark comparison to 101, which was  much much easier.

There are several distinct pros and cons of this course:

Pros:
--Incredible material that was engaging, exciting and challenging.
--Peer tutors were great!

Cons:
--Not much peer support.
--Not enough tutors and bad times (only two time slots in the week that were inconveinent)
--Not enough review sessions.
--Our teacher was quite confusing at times. He was unable to simplify material sometimes.
--My TA was awful...to the point where she would consistently tell us wrong information during our sections...more on this below.

strength: learn a lot, passionate teacher

Weaknesses: teacher speaks way to fast,
This class could be taught slower with more explanations.

The lecture goes over way too much material. It can be hard to tell what material is relevant and what material is unimportant (the notes about learning goals can be really vague). There are very few grades. The stuff is learnable but it's hard to tell what stuff we should learn.

I had to take this course for my major. If you don't need to take it for a requirement, then please please please save yourself the time and energy and do not take it. There are easier, more useful science credits out there. Often, I was left wondering when I would really use the material, even though I found it interesting. If you don't find tiny details of cells very interesting and won't be interested in the material, the class will be pretty awful for you as you're going to have to put in a lot of work. That being said, if you put in an excessive amount of work and try very hard, you will receive proportionate results.

Do not take this course unless it is a requirement for your major. The teacher looks like Santa Claus and he's a sweetheart but he's also a mumbler who is too intelligent to know how to explain information to uninformed students.
I would not recommend this course with this professor. If someone had to take this course, I would recommend that they take it during the spring with the other professor.
I mean, if you have to take the bio sequence for a pre-req then you have no choice.  But it's a pretty mediocre class.

I recommend this course to the students who are required to take it, of course, but if it is not required I would not recommend it. The course is a wonderful course, but it is not the type of thing you take for fun. To fully understand the material you must be committed to not only going to lecture, but to seeking extra help through the peer tutor sessions, teaching fellows, and/or enrichment sessions. It is a very different style of learning from any previous biology course students have taken and requires a lot of work to understand fully. Some may have found this easy if they have already worked in labs, but for the vast majority this class would not be something taken for fun.

Well it depends on what major path or career path the student is going on. If they want to do something in stem and they enjoy science, then I would recommend this since it's a pretty solid introductory course. For anyone else, I probably wouldn't recommend it just because it's difficult to really develop any care towards the subject.

I would only recommend this course to a student who needs to take biology for their major. The volume of the material could be overwhelming and the sheer number of details was burdensome (not that you had to know all the details, but you didn't always know what you had to know!). Nevertheless, congratulations to Professor Mooseker for designing a challenging and effect college-level biology course!

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in further study in the biological sciences or premedical-required courses. It would be a challenge to those that don't find the information interesting.

Yes! It provides a very different, experiment-based approach to biology giving you a similar view to what a researcher's life would be like.

It was helpful to read the slides before class so I could ask questions about the experiments in class. I took notes beforehand so I could follow along with the fast pace of the class (which I enjoyed).

Yes. This is a fast-paced and content-heavy course, but it is engaging and fascinating. Professor Mooseker is great at making himself accessible to students as a resource and is a very valuable asset to have. This course is challenging but is certainly worthwhile.
Only if you need to take this course! Otherwise, take a more interesting course!
While this class is difficult, you will learn a lot.
Yes, I would recommend this class if you need it as a prereq.
I would not recommend this course to anyone that didn't have to take it for their major.

Any student looking at this course probably has to take it. Here is some advice: Mooseker is a really great professor, but his lectures go extremely fast and he can be very confusing at times. However, without a doubt he is the only good thing about this version of 102. The tests were very hard, most (luckily not mine) of the TS could not care any less about teaching, and the other students likely have way more research experience that you. Beware that the psets are very confusing, the lectures are super long, and you will need to put a TON of time into studying for the exams if you want to do well. The content of the course is great, but the intro bio sequence will make you really despise biology if you don't come in prepared.
For someone genuinely interested in Cell Biology, this is a great course. It could be painful for anyone else.
I would recommend to another student but would advise them that they have to stay on top of material in order to succeed

I would recommend this course if you need to take it (pre-med, MCDB, MBB, etc.) but if you're not a STEM major or have a remote interest in STEM, then I don't think it's really worth to take because it's very concentrated on papers, experiments, pathways, etc. which was really great for learning and developing skills in scientific critical thinking skills, but if you're not interested in that, then do not take it. It's a pretty stark change from 101 - different change of pace in how much material we go through than 101 but forces you to be engaged in class
only take it if you have to. It's hard.
Prerequisites aside, this would be an ideal course to learn how scientific reasoning in biology is grounded in experiments and evidence.

Yes, I would. This class teaches you to have accountability for your engagement. If you slack and don't attend any out of class sessions, you will likely suffer in class. If you stay on top of things, you can succeed. Good class to take with you throughout your time at Yale.

I would recommend this course to any individuals who would like to major in something that is STEM related since it may steer them away from that decision. Although it is definitely a challenging course, it is one that is necessary for any individuals who wish to be premed or even major in something related to biology.

I would recommend this course to another student. I think a lot of the information is fundamental to further study in cell biology and the life science field at large. I also believe that Biol 102 really challenged a lot of my work habits and study skills, calling on me to engage on a deeper level with the material, and these are critical thinking/problem solving skills that all students should develop, especially in STEM.
Yes, this course may be difficult, but it is worth taking, especially if you are going into a field of biology.
Only if they had to take bio for their major.
Yes, this class was a great opportunity for me to build my skills of critical thinking in a scientific setting, which I think is one of the most important aspects of learning.
Only if required for their major or for premed. This class isn't one I would recommend if someone was looking for a science class.
Not unless you have to take this course. Not the most fun biology class offered. Feels more like a chore than anything else.
Yes, if ou are interested in bio I would say take the course. But it is a lot of work, and you have to be committed to the class.

I would never recommend this course unless you had to for the major. If you're looking for a science credit to satisfy graduation requirements, know that there are so many more interesting and easier science classes at Yale worth taking. This class is not exciting and is too much work for anyone who isn't seriously considering a life science major. Not worth the time.

Yes becuase it is necessary, and also because the material is very interesting. However, you must be prepared to do a great deal of outside work to even understand the base concepts. the lectures themselves were very uninformative

Yes, I absolutely would. Great course, even greater teacher! Pro-tip, sit in the front of the class if you want to understand anything at all! The learning curve is steep but it gets less so if you take control of your own learning.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. It is great for building a foundational knowledge of cell bio, and also for teaching how to think like a scientist. I think it's a great into course.
Pre-meds and bio majors will likely have to take this class and while it can be difficult and confusing, the knowledge gained will be extremely useful.
I would recommend this class to another student, but I would make sure that they knew that this course required a lot of work and was very intellectually challenging.
Yes. If you have any interest in eventual pursuit a biology research, I would say this class is a must-take.
No, I don't like how impersonal and fast paced the lecture style was.
Though it may not be rewarding enough for non science majors to take, science majors will enjoy the class.
only if it is a major for a requirement you are confident about
Solid class, interesting material. Take it if you're interested in bio.
Yes.
Yes
Take it if you have to. Don't take it for fun.
I would recommend this course to another student. I feel that I have a greater appreciation for the field of cell biology.
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are pre-med, as this course helps greatly with real-life problem solving and understanding research. However, I would caution the student that this class is more challenging than average and definitely required active engagement to learn and truly understand all the concepts.
Yes, if it is a prerequisite
I would recommend the course.
Do not take this class in the fall. Wait and take it in the spring.
If you are STEM or premed you have to take it but I did not enjoy this course at all.
Absolutely. Professor Mooseker is very engaging, funny and prioritizes your understanding.
Only if you are truly interested in the subject.
Yes. Great prof, interesting material
No. But you're not taking it for fun anyway.
It was very challenging and made you think outside the box

Many (if not all) are taking this because it is required. This is definitely more difficult than BIOL 101, and I would recommend taking advantage of peer tutors, review sessions, and lecture outlines/learning goals to keep up with the material.
Dont take this with Mooseker. He will trash your GPA and leave you scrambling to get everything down on paper. You have been warned.

While I had heard from other students that the instructor for off-season BIOL102 ran a significantly easier course, I would recommend taking Professor Mooseker's course. He does not mess around, but he is clearly so knowledgeable, experienced, and passionate in his field that he grew to become one of my favorite instructors at Yale. I'd recommend the class!
Take this course for credit as a premed student or science major

If I am being honest, this course is extremely disorganized. I love biology and this course left me feeling confused and frustrated. I can appreciate the fact that the professor is very passionate and knowledgeable but his lessons are so scattered it is extremely hard to follow his line of thought.  I believe this course made the content unnecessarily confusing. I think there is great opportunity to learn here. I liked what I learned about, but be prepared to teach it all to yourself.

No, don't take this course if you don't have to. 

While Moosker might be a great researcher who discovered endosomes or whatever, he is not a good teacher. He is not able to teach in a simple manner and instead complicates every concept. Just say stuff clearer man!! 

At times, this course was felt very frustrating. It was like trying to teach us how to swim using words. It never threw us in the water and got our feet wet.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it it necessary for them to take it:

Overall, I though BIOL 102 with Professor Mooseker was excellent, and I would certainly recommend it. It's by no means an easy class, but the material offered a good amount of challenge, and I found it very interesting. There was always plenty of support: Professor Mooseker offers weekly review sessions, which are very helpful for reinforcing hard concepts or picking up details you missed in lecture, my section had reviews before the midterm and final, and the peer tutors are generally very helpful.

If you have to take this class, then yes. If you do not absolutely have to take this class, then I would definitely not recommend it because the class is very rigorous and the material is sort of interesting if you understand it but it can also be a bit dry and quite dense and confusing.

I would highly recommend this course to anyone at Yale. If you are interested in biology, I would especially recommend this course. I think that all students could benefit from learning the fundamentals of biology. I think this course was run very well and the professor was very knowledgeable

No if you have any option not to take it avoid the intro bio sequence at all cost.  Total waste of time. As a pre-need student it was mildly helpful but didnt teach me the basics of bio I need to know.
Anyone interested in cell biology should take this class to order to understand the basic science and experimental background of the field.

I would absolutely recommend this class, and I think it would also be fascinating for students not looking to go into STEM. Professor Mooseker and the TFs went put a lot of effort into making the class incredibly efficient and well-run. It is a remarkable course, and even though the content covered in the past six weeks was a lot, it was a very valuable learning experience.
I have definitely developed my understanding of biology in an in-depth way. I am able to analyze and apply my knowledge instead of simply stating facts.
Yes! A lot of work, but really interesting.
Only if you need it for your major
I would recommend this course only if the student was willing to put the time and effort that this class requires.
Yes, it was a fantastic course and I developed skills that will help me in other courses at Yale.
Yes, it's a standard cell bio intro class.

I would not recommend this course to any student unless it is a prerequisite for their major or to fulfill pre-med requirements. Although the course is set up to be useful and interesting and the professors and teaching scholars are dedicated to your learning, the students in the course are motivated by interests other than learning for learning's sake. As a result, the environment of the course is less intellectually stimulating and more annoying.

Yes, but only if you're truly interested in the cell membrane and/or different experimental methods, or if you have to take it as a requirement. Professor Mooseker made the course extremely interesting, especially with his in-class demonstrations.
Mm, honestly don't take this if you don't have to.
Only take if you have to. There is a lot to memorise and the lectures are all over the place.
No because it isn't helpful and is far from an intro biology class.
Yes but not as a way of completing a distributional requirement
I would recommend this class to other students but perhaps with a warning that much of the biology needed for something like the MCAT has to be learned outside of the class.

Unsure. After studying for the exams you will leave feeling very prepared in cellular biology. However it takes a long time to adjust to the teaching style and there is a lot of material to master that you will likely have never seen before (it is well-beyond the scope of AP Bio).
Only take this course if it is a pre-req or you have already learnt all the information in high school.
Yes if one wants to go beyond pure memorization and learn how to think scientifically i recommend this course
Yes if interested in biology

I found lecture for this course badly organized and more confusing than the material warranted. Since it's required for so many STEM majors, my advice is to take notes from the lecture slides but not attend lecture at allthat system was both more time efficient for me and led to a much better understanding of the material in general.

I think that this course taught me to really break down experiments like a scientist, and to really commit to learning and understanding the subject matter. I would recommend it for that, however,  it is also a requirement so STEM majors have no choice,

I would not recommend this course to another student, yet I doubt most students taking the course have any choice. The lectures are disorganized and will not provide you with the foundational knowledge you need to understand the material being taught. It was frustrating and confusing. I realized too late that I was wasting time attending lecture-- I only learned the material when I went through the hundreds of lecture slides on my own right before the final. The homework assignments were equally confusing-- my study group spent a lot of time trying to figure out if the questions contained errors or if we were really supposed to know how to solve them.
Yes, if the student is very interested in biology and in research.  No, if the student is not interested or is looking for an easy course.
Yes. But only to students who are prepared for a very tough course.
I wouldn't recommend this course to a non stem major or someone looking to fulfill their science requirment. This class requires a lot of effort and interest
Yes
Only if you have to take it.
